ResponseText:
1. User agency — default-deny permissions, per-action consent for sensitive tasks, easy off switch, and clear “AI receipts” of what it saw/did with sources.

2. Accountability — independent audits, data minimization/on-device options, instant restitution for harms, fast human escalation.

3. Equity & resilience — accessible, multilingual, offline/fail-safe, data portability, and transparency on updates & environmental impact.
Tag 3: Data privacy, security, and user control

ResponseText: Human emotions significantly influence decision-making, but using AI to quantify and quantify human emotions often leads to errors. This is because human emotions are influenced by different environments and experiences, and each person's worldview varies. AI cannot completely replace humans in making final decisions.
Human has two parts, logical and emotional. The survey seems to lean a little more towards the logical side of human-AI interactions.

I agree and support AI's health management capabilities, but as someone with a medical background, I am certain that data alone cannot reflect a person's health status. Moreover, rational analysis alone may not necessarily lead to a satisfactory treatment plan. There are many non-objective factors involved, such as the wishes of the patient and their family, as well as religious and cultural influences, etc.

ResponseText: Questions regarding what i want AI to manage and what i dont what it to manage. I am more than capable of taking care of my appointments and my healthcare needs. I trust my intellect and decision making to work more in my favor than any other entity, human/AI. But what i want is for the AI with some combination of robots to order groceries, to cook, to clean around the house.

Regarding labor issues, I believe AI reduces task time, but this won't benefit workers, who will simply accumulate more tasks within their work schedule, which won't be reduced. I believe it will be yet another task serving employers and won't have the desired impact on people, nor will it make life easier for the masses, only for those who can save resources and will continue to fail to distribute profits appropriately.

ResponseText: Regarding my specific views on the future development of artificial intelligence, of course, since I am a practitioner, I know more, which may not be suitable for the general public.

Regarding the discussion of artificial intelligence consciousness: I believe that artificial intelligence is currently just a probabilistic prediction model. The autoregressive language model can essentially imitate human language behavior, but it does not contain self-awareness and does not understand what it says. Everything conforms to the probability distribution of the output.

ResponseText: Yes — one important point is that while AI can be incredibly helpful, it should always support human judgment, not replace it completely. Encouraging users to stay critical, ask questions, and verify important info is just as important as improving the AI itself.
